text: so um before my joyous period of semi-retirement um which has given me a lot of time to
think i spent 10 years at google a couple of years at skyscanner and for the last 10 years i've been very interested in
what makes teams high-performing i've also had a lot of material to work with because i've
either managed directly or indirectly a large number of teams and back on us at google i was part of
rolling out the project aristotle work on effective teams so i spent not in considerable part of
my life talking to people in fairly broken situations and one of the common themes that i've
seen in teams particularly ones which are performing well is their relationship with time
and the teams which are really high performing seem to have more time than everybody else to get things done
they're never hurried they always hit their deadlines they have flex they're able to take on new crises as they show up
and teams which are struggling never have enough time and they'll always feel like they're behind and they're under pressure and this has a
serious knock-on effects and the way we think about time can help us have a much greater impact
in our life now benjamin franklin said that time is money and if time is the most valuable
currency that we have as human beings on this planet we have a finite amount of it once it's
gone we don't get to earn more of it unfortunately and therefore every moment
of our existence is a precious piece of currency and i'd like to thank you for investing some of
your personal currency and coming to listen to me today when maybe the pub was calling and you're a bit burned out from the other
talks i'd also like to thank speakers before me who have given me colossal imposter syndrome for your excellent and
insightful talks today and hopefully i will live up to their high standards so let's start with why
why why should we care um what is your company care can you have more impact in less time
one of the things which was brought up earlier was people need to instill a sense of urgency into the teams
actually it's about having more effect in a shorter space of time from a personal perspective the more
impact you have the faster you progress your career and if you're able to do that without it
consuming your whole life you have a personal life to go with that as well and that should not be underestimated
and before i get into the full meat of this i would like to offer some words of warning here um
first of all for the managers in the room change comes from within it is very very
difficult to externally force a change on another human being
if you would like to try this i have a small social experiment so take out a pen turn to the person next to you and try
and write idiot across their forehead i guarantee you are going to have a really hard time making this change
happen if they choose the right idiot that's another matter and probably self-fulfilling
second of all you need to lead by example if you are not walking the walk in terms of how you're
using your time and other people's time nobody else is going to either and in fact the limiting factor on
organizations is how their leaders behave and how they use their time and actually employ people around
them lastly using time well is not being busy busyness is a curse and actually having
time where you're not busy where you're available to take on things as they come up because they will is
vitally important the more senior you get the more important it is to have that flex time um
finally when i stopped working i had about 200 people working for me and if i was not keeping half of my week free of
meetings then i was not able to be there when people needed me either for support for
guidance for air cover or any of the random things which happens to human beings in
their lives the last thing while thinking about time
can help teams progress themselves as a manager the last thing you should do
is try and measure the time people are spending on things in particular do not try and centralize
the measurement of how people are managing time that is one of the fastest ways to get people to quit their jobs
believe me it really really is as soon as my manager says what were you doing at 11 o'clock this morning like i don't know
concentrate on outcomes but this is a set of principles which will enable you to become more effective
please do not use my teaching for evil so first of all what is the value of time this is uh an
interesting question you can think of it a number of ways um back in the day i was on call for part of google's ad business which at
the time was worth about 10 billion revenue a year i can very quickly
extrapolate the value of this now i also was on call during
both the fukushima nuclear disaster and hurricane sandy in new york where
the internet was about 36 hours away from being bifurcated because most of the networking across
the atlantic goes into one building in downtown manhattan and that was flooded and the water levels were rising
steadily the stress when things go wrong is quite high and if you look at it you can lose
27 million dollars in a day which is both motivating and terrifying
at the same time in that instance it is well worth employing a number of people to make
sure the system is running smoothly on a full-time basis but that may not be the best use of all of their time
what's your time worth to you i did a quick search on glassdoor and the average software engineer in
london earns 52 000 pounds a year which if we extrapolate that out works
out at roughly 200 pounds a day but cost of employing somebody is double
that so to your company just the cost of your time
is 400 pounds a day now that's before any return on your investment
let's assume that your company gets back a pound in revenue and they break even your time spent not working
is worth 800 pounds a day to your company if you are profitable you are your time
is worth 1200 pounds a day to your company now a simple sum means i can work out the cost of qcon
which is not going to endear me to the organizers but if you look at the cost of everybody
being here it's about 2.8 million once you throw in the cost of your time
in terms of paying you for your normal employment and the opportunity cost of you not being here
it works out over 5 million pounds to your company you could probably start a couple of
kickr startups for that kind of money and this is three days of people's time so what i'm saying
thank you for investing this time this has real value and it's a little bit scary once you
work the numbers out um back when i was at google my first manager who was
deeply misanthropic shared an essay on philosophy with me called the basic laws of stupidity now
at the time i thought he was celebrating our shared hatred of the human species and looking back i realized what he was
trying to say was stop doing stupid things and i have adapted this to how people spend
time now you can look at it as quadrants there's two axes across the bottom is the value you're
bringing to yourself up the side is the value you're bringing to others now
the intelligent person brings value to themselves and to people around them if we were to
use an analogy of pies for this an intelligent person makes a bigger pie so people can eat more
a person who indulges in a zero-sum game takes your pie and eats it for themselves
a person who is hapless doesn't know there's pie being served and therefore doesn't have an opportunity to eat
and people who are harmful start a food fight with the pie so that nobody gets to eat and when we're thinking about how we
spend our time think about the value we're bringing to ourselves if we are not in the top right quadrant
we are either not going to be very happy with life or we're going to be causing harm to other people and by the way there's not really such a
thing as a zero-sum game because if you're in a work relationship with somebody and your success is
predicated on them losing something the next time you interact with them is going to be
much harder for you therefore you want to create these situations where everyone's success is alike
somebody in a team who sees everybody else get promoted when they've been working just as hard as everybody else
but has no route to promotion to themselves is not likely to support the team's success
in the long term so this comes to four things i hope to be true with high
performing team's relationship with time the first is they invest in how they use time
over a period of time they are getting better over time second they respect other people's time
now when i started this talk after 30 years in the industry and i realized that we have a real
problem in our industry and how we respect each other's time there are about 500 slides of people who
have pissed me off over the years and wasted my time and once i got that cathartically out of my system i realized i had to reframe it
into something positive i have a lot of examples and both good use of time and not so good use of time
which we will get to they're ruthless about time they don't do things which don't bring them value
they are willing to say no to things which don't make sense and lastly they're able to anticipate
things in advance they know that there are unknown unknowns in any situation and yet they're able to
mitigate them effectively in the course of getting things done so that they're not crippling to what they're working on
so let's start with investment improvement so first of all at any point in time if you talk to
somebody in an engineering team and say how are things going they're likely to say everything is
because they look at the things which are stopping them getting things done and there are going to be no situations in your
life where somebody comes to you and says it is too easy to get things done here
you are never going to have that conversation as a manager which is kind of sad um and if you look at a single data
point you are never going to be a happy person it's very easy to join that person in a kind of mutual despair at how the
world is so unfair and you're swimming through treacle and it's never going to get better if you have two data points however you
have an opportunity to have a real conversation about things if your trajectory is up and to the right then
you can talk about what other things we did which enabled us to get better how do we do more of those things and by the way if
we were like that six months ago and six months time we're going to be up here and things are going to be much better again let's keep doing this if things are down
and to the right you have a problem but you now have an opportunity to course correct that problem it could be you're
generating too much tech debt it could be that there's not enough domain knowledge in the team it could be people are leaving
with him it could be the requirements are broken but knowing the trajectory across different data points means you can
chart that the team's doing well and you have that feedback loop to tell them keep doing the things that you're doing
um if you have a team which is struggling with time first question you should ask them is
how easy is it to do the simple things i had a team
a few years back where they hadn't actually pushed to production in three years they were not happy with life and they
had just inherited the code base for a quite large number of millions of users
product from another team with not much support on how to get things done and they had a lot of
pressure from part of the organization around support costs for that product and one of the things that they wanted
to change was actually a button uh it took them five weeks to change
that button once they've gone through the privacy reviews the legal reviews the testing the internationalization the experiments to
demonstrate it was having the effect it was going to have now this is not particularly motivating
but this is the shortest cycle time they could go through to learn how to get better
and the teams which are really great are the ones that make the simple things look effortless a change which should
take an hour to get from conception to production takes an hour and how you get them down that journey
is how many times you can go through that cycle reducing steps every single time if a team is struggling and you give them
a 18-month project to invent a new tech they're never going to deliver it so
when a team is having a hard time start them with the simple things once you get good at the simple things
then you can progress to things which are more complicated um the next question is um the eternal
friction between product and engineering so product wants features and the business want features
engineering wants to build infrastructure this is the wrong question what if the
team is the product what if part of the work you're doing is to make your team as effective as
possible and invest in that what are the feedback loops and conversations which need to happen to enable that to happen
i'll also say as well if you're not investing in moving faster as a team and removing friction you're going to be
moving slower because you're going to be accruing tech debts short-term gain i had another team who were really
really struggling with this and to the point where their weekly sprint
goals that they were missing like 85 of them and their stakeholders were
quite vocal about things not going well um and we came to an alignment that well
before we try and come up with your six month plan and a plan for these milestones which by the way if we can't plan over a week there's no point trying
to plan over six months that is cruel and unusual punishment why don't we get to the point where we
deliver on our promises every week so at the end of every week we'll look at whether we achieve what we said we
were going to achieve now if we did great if we didn't
why not okay is there a way of adding something to the backlog which will allow us to move quicker next week
and we found that kind of a one two week cycle gave us a good number of iterations
where we can make small cumulative improvements where you get the compound interest of like two three four percent gains which don't
feel like much at a time but over the course of a year can turn a team into a completely different creature altogether
it also gives ownership to the team over how they go about working if the
team is not investing in making their lives better they are going to be pretty miserable and that sense of ownership and purpose
cannot be underestimated this is the one which might take a bit of time and i need to not turn into a
big ranty shout respecting each other's time um
even more years ago i used to work with somebody who um they worked kind of seven o'clock till three o'clock in the afternoon
because they had family commitments and on friday afternoon at lunchtime when they went home they committed all their code into cvs
which is how long ago it was uh and just went home now so the problem
here was there were no unit tests and they hadn't even bothered to compile their code so for the next
eight or nine hours the rest of the team basically were forced into debugging
their code in fact this was the motivator in my life towards test driven development so that i could quickly work through
the chain of suffering that this person's changes had come through
time is also the basis of trust if time is the most valuable currency we have if other people are spending our most
precious commodity and then not spending it well this is not going to lead to a healthy
relationship between us and the way we spend each other's time is as important or maybe more so in a
high performing team than the way we spend our own time and thinking about using each other's
time as constructively as possible and bringing value to other people with your interactions
is the bedrock of every high trust high performing team

now interruption is an interesting thing because

what you do see when teams behave well is a set of behaviors which is quite uplifting

that's not a good way to be and we agreed that actually the person who's given

because people realized that somebody had invested in them in fact research shows that if people
don't say thank you for you doing something you are half as likely to help them in future
that's pretty terrifying they volunteer to help each other one of the highest performing teams i've ever managed
any time one of the team was going through a launch everybody else would drop what they were doing

and they had that safety net because they were all invested in each other's success they had the highest promotion rate of

and when they spend each other's time they spend it respectfully they spend it well if you're not seeing those behaviors in your team

um i thought we had technical problems for a moment um right so this
is a life-changing piece of magic um for the last year of my life i've spent a lot of time coaching people at
director or soon to be director level and one of the common threads which runs through their existence is there are not
enough hours in the day to get stuff done the more senior you get the more the
demands on your time grows in fact it grows exponentially and this is eisenhower's matrix and you rate things
about by whether how important they are and what urgency they are and if you want to understand how broken
your life is you can get a team to write down all of the tasks and responsibilities they have and put it in one of these quadrants and
depending on which quadrants they're in you can tell them fairly quickly where the problem lies
so first of all anything in the top right corner if it's urgent and important it's a crisis if all of your things are
in crisis mode people are going to burn out pretty quickly if things are urgent but not important
they are a distraction but the problem is is we tend to work on the things where people are noisiest
and in a situation where people have got lots of um low importance higher urgency requests
where they just are impatient for answers typically what happens is we do the things which are in distraction before
the important things which are not urgent and then what happens is the important things which are not
urgent become urgent and now rather than working on the things which are highest importance
to us in a deliberate and controlled manner we are now doing them from a reactionary
panicked manner which means the quality of work is going to be less understand where things sit on these
quadrants um ignore the trivia admittedly if you're just ignoring something someone's asked you to do you should probably tell
them about it as a courtesy but you shouldn't be working on these things you should only be working on the
things which bring the most value at any point in time and high performing teams know what are
the most important tasks they can be working on now for anyone who has worked for me

i was not the most popular person in that team and actually seeing the effect that had
on them was astonishing so first of all when they had been told to cancel previous goals
they hadn't been allowed to delete the code from the code base so they were still on the hook for supporting services that they weren't allowed to go
and spend time fixing as the infrastructure changed underneath them this was taking about two person days a
week of effort just to keep the lights on on these things second of all if you think that your
work is going to be thrown away in six months time or just stopped you have no incentive you are not
committed to getting things done you are not committed to high quality you don't really care because it doesn't
matter and it took a while to work through the implications of that in fact the
promise i made to them upon the fifth change was first of all you're going to work on the goal that i
am most excited about so you have the most high profile thing i have um which also means
you deal with me a lot so there are downsides to this second of all if they change your goal in six months time i'm just going to
quit on the spot because this can't happen again and even then it took a year for any kind of trust to
regrow in that relationship it's incredibly painful because when you change
it's not just a case of all right tomorrow we're working on this you have to disentangle yourself in the previous situations
people might have careers which are based upon a feature like they won't get promoted unless something's delivered so their
personal interest is not aligned with what's happening and it's the if you'd done nothing for six

make it better also think about the skills that you need in order to
cut down on waste of time so um most companies have 360 feedback
and promo processes and every six to 12 months everything stops for a month while everyone tries to figure out how
to do that in a way which isn't going to offend their colleagues and we're crap at giving feedback and if
you're spending two weeks of your life writing feedback because you're not sure how to give it effectively that's not a good use of time you could
spend a day learning how to give feedback effectively and get everything done in an afternoon surely that's a
good investment of time writing technical design documents also we're not great at writing emails
um have you ever written an email which is five pages long and you've polished it to the point
where it gleams in the sun making your point and then no one actually opened and read it
right people don't read email longer than about two paragraphs how do we allow people to write more
effectively so that the people reading it can make a decision sooner rather than having to consume more information we are constantly beset
with too much information in our day jobs if we're better at sending it in condensed and useful form for each other
we save everybody time so being ruthless with time is about
working on the highest value things at any point in time it's about being willing to say this brings no value and to invest your
time in something which is going to bring you value it's about keeping sub teams small it's about not
having everybody in every single situation even though that feels like the inclusive things to do it's about communicating directly with
people so that you're not having multiple context hops or you need a decision you talk to your manager they talk to their manager they
talk to their manager then they talk back down and like a week later you hear what the decision is without any of the context associated
with it those things are crippling to the productivity of happiness and effectiveness of teams
and lastly great teams anticipate problems they are able to deal with ambiguity in
a way which seems almost magical
we know that the cost of resolving a problem versus the time required to detect the
problem raises exponentially and yet we still build these massive waterfall charts where we do the easy things first
and then the hard things we defer until the end of our project we still plan for the golden path where
everything works out fine even though history tells us that every time we do this we have a really bad time we still
spend the first three months of a six month project blissfully happy that everything's going well
and then like somebody trying to hand in their university homework cram it into the last few nights and burn ourselves out we still do this
and in fact part of the problem is plans um this is a great quote because this is
exactly how i feel about it your plan is wrong i can say that with a high
degree of confidence without even looking at it because no plan of any complexity
can possibly account for all of the things which are going to go wrong along the way people will get sick
you'll be adopting a new technology which you haven't necessarily understood all of the implications of
requirements will change the law will change in some cases the reality is the act of planning to
understand the shape of what you're trying to achieve is an incredibly powerful activity because it gives you a rough feeling of the shape of what
you're trying to achieve but in its worst situation a plan is deeply disempowering for a team
i'm going to give you a couple of examples one which went really badly and one which kind of went well so another team i had they were working
on a large-scale migration from one system to another and they had a multi-hundred line
spreadsheet of all of the tasks which were required to get from a to b and against each task they had a
percentage done and every week 15 people for an hour and a half got in a room and they were asked individually um what
percentage are you through this that's 83 okay that's good that's right my next one all right and
it was a month before the project was supposed to be shipped everything was on track three months later project hadn't been
shipped because they weren't talking about the outcomes they were trying to achieve the project plan had
become the outcome and it became about showing that the plan was green and on track
as the thing they were trying to achieve rather than focusing on the actual problem they were trying to solve
for the people working on this this prevented them from actually coming up with more intelligent solutions to the
problems in front of them because they needed to fit them to the actual plan of delivery that they were
working against rather than trying to understand the problem the context they were operating against and when we ran the retro for that
project um people had ptsd from filling in the spreadsheet it was like i never want to go back to
this place please don't make me go there okay it's okay so i'll get out everything's fine i'm like no we don't
want to hug you i'm fine okay so whilst planning is great
understand that your plan is subject to change the more complicated your plan the
greater the amount of time you're going to spend correcting it when it does change because a plan which you make six months
ago and has changed you don't update is equally harmful and therefore if you're thinking about the time you're
investing in keeping your plan up to date this is also time you could be spending on something else a good rule of thumb
is use the smallest amount of process possible in order to be effective and
anything more than that is just vanity for the people running the processes apologies to the project managers in the
room but this is about the plan is a tool to solve a problem it is not the solution in and of itself

fairly large fine along the way here when you are planning towards a non-negotiable deadline
work from the basis that everything is going to fail and in fact some rules for planning um if your plan
does not include the ability to cope with your inevitable failure it is wrong how do you plan to
fail as cheaply as possible as early in the process as possible so you have the opportunity to solve things
um one of the conversations you never want to have as a software engineer with your management or the ceo of the
company is so you know we were going to launch today um we're actually kind of not
and we don't know when we're going to be ready to launch those are not enjoyable conversations to
have the sooner you understand that your plan is wrong the sooner you're able to align your stakeholders with that and have an adult
conversation about what you drop in terms of scope if the deadline is non-negotiable or how you
change the team dynamics to actually deliver on things your plan is not free to maintain make it as cheap
as possible make it as meaningful as possible to maintain that plan when you're talking about
delivery of tasks or milestones what are the things preventing us getting this done is much more empowering conversation than
what percentage are we through this that might be something you ask is a sanity check but if it's the only
question you ask bad things are going to happen and your plan will become the outcome in that situation people are very good
at delivering outcomes but it does not lead to the delivery of high quality software and then finally and this is like just
to reinforce the accelerate book which i'm sure most people have read how quickly you can recover from
failure also determines the level of risk you're willing to take on in your plan because if it takes you a month to
change something in production after the error has been detected you probably want to catch things earlier in
the process and invest in that rather than assuming you can just fix things on the fly
so if you're developing an operating system for a nuclear submarine for example where it may not surface for six months
